text: Roasted, almost burnt malt in aroma. Minimal carbonation. Lively herbaceous and bitter stuff going on against the malt notes. Great example of the style.

Bottle from Sainsburys. pours clear ruby brown with thin white head. Aromas strong with toffee front then blackcurrant jam and cola cubes. Taste is sweet, light, malty fruit loaf with warm spice and orange peel. It has a soft body and light sparkle. This is a beautifully warm, light, spicy, fruity ale. A traditional ale in the spirit of a fruit cake.
From old tasting notes. Deep orange brown color topped by a rocky beige head. Rich caramel malt aroma. Rich bittersweet roasted malt flavor hints at molasses and apple cider. Long bitter aftertaste.
Pours brown. Aroma is sweet fig. Taste is fussel, taste is very malty, dark fruits, toffee. Rough and ready but quite tasty

Bottle. Deep Amber in colour. Very, very malty (Roast malts, burnt sugar, caramel, toffee, some liquorice). Fruity (dark fruits and raisins). Hoppy (slight balancing hop bitterness) Very sweet malty fruity throughout. Too sweet for my taste. (2008)
500ml bottle at home. Somewhat pale amber with a small white head. Medium body with low to moderate carbonation. Nice subtle bitter and sweet tones. Malts, caramel and nuts. Nice.

Bottle 50cl. poured into a half pint glass. Clear medium to deep amber, good two finger creamy beige head, mostly lasting, heavy lacing; aroma toasted malts, caramel, bread, nuts; taste medium sweet and bitter, malty, roasted, toffee, nutty, bit alcohol; aftertaste sweet and slightly bitter, lingering roasted malts, nutty and spicy notes; medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation; nice and tasty one.

.l bottle. Dark orange/ruby body, thin white head. Aroma of toast, caramel, roasted malts, orange zest and floral hops. Taste of toast, caramel, orange zest and raisins with floral and spicy hops. Easy to drink yet flavourful. I love it.

L:
-pours a clear copper-red with a medium frothy,offwhite head
-low to medium carbonation visible
S:
-caramel,toffee,plums,raisins,strawbe the nose plus roasty coffee & Nutty notes with a slight spicy bitterniss
F:
-low to medium,soft carbonation
-light to medium body
-slight alcohol note as it warms
O:
Advice for this Beer: Do not drink it cold.This really opens up at Room temp.
great overall.

(bottle) Clear, ruby brown colour with a medium-sized tanned foamy head. Mildly nutty and slightly bready malty aroma with notes of caramel and discreetly fruity accents. Moderately sweet flavour, medium bodied with a calm carbonation. Slightly toasted malty base with caramel, nutty hints and slightly candied fruity notes, getting a tad vinous towards the sweet and cautious bitter finish, alongside with a whiff of earthy hops. Not bad. 06.II.16

Dobry mocny bitterek. Ciemno rubinowa barwa i naprawde bardzo spora piana jak na brytyjskie Ale. Mogla by nieco dluzej sie utrzymac. Smak konkretny tresciwy i gozki rownoczesnie bardzo slodowe, bogata struktura tego Ale dac moze mieszane uczucia dla jednych bedzie bardzo gozki a dla innych bardzo slodowy. Jak dla mnie perfekcyjnie zbalansowane te dwa przeciwstawne doznania. Polecam to sprawdzic
Bottle. Light malty aroma. Tasty beast of ale, with plenty of body and malt character.

Bottle, 6.7%. Dark brown with small tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, little toasted, hop and a little chocolate. Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, little dark fruit, little chocolate, medium sweet and a little bitter.
Bottle. Frothy White good mostly lasting head. ´Dark amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. oily palate.

(bottle) clear amber-ruby colour with a frothy beige head. aroma of bubble gum and marzipan, with soft notes of butterscotch, some pale malts, caramel and cherries. flavour is mostly bubble gum and gently toasted malts, with more cherries, some sugar icing, yeast and some walnuts in the semi-dry finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

500 ml bottle clear caramel color with creamy white head. taste are some kind light barley sweetness wit lots of dried apple and plums taste and some kind toffee notes rich beer in taste and has long stayng aftertaste with notes of dried fruits and alcohol. to many alcohol in aftertaste. and a bit sticky.
Birra squisita, con evidenti sentori biscottati, maltati, un po caramellati e freschi, come di liquirizia.

Bottle.
Very malty and well balanced beer 
Some winey and passito and mature fruit
DØE. Clear dark amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and dark fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 290515
Very dark colour with a surprisingly sweet flavour followed by a bitter after taste overall a very pleasant drink.
Bottle at KØ15. Clear dark brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, fruit, yeast, hops and bitterness.

Klare orangebraune Farbe, ordentlich große leicht beige Schaumkrone. Geruch karamellig, leicht schokoladig, nussig, reife Früchte. Geschmack karamellig, dezent hopfig bitter, leicht schokoladig, nussig, gut!

Pours a deep dark chestnut brown, with a thick creamy head. Aroma has notes of peat, rich toasty malts, toffee, and brown sugar. Taste has notes of rich grains, toasty malts, toffee, and peat. Excellent beer!

Bottle, KØ15. Pours clear darkish copper brown with airy off-white head. Clear aroma of malt, fruit and yeast, with mild hoppy notes. Sweetish, malty flavour with notes of caramel and fruit and bitter, hoppy touches. Estery and bitterish aftertaste. A nice one.

500ml bottle, pours a deep copper red when held to the light, decent light tan head that dissipates after a minute or two. Initial nose is nutty, malty caramel. Sweet, malty and toasty taste giving way to a lightly hopped finish and long lasting warmth. Great! Good balance, tasty and easy drinking.

Consistently sound, Old Jock is an old school Scotch Ale which sits right in the middle of the style. Very well balanced between malt and hop this is awarming beer which hits well above its modest ABV.

500 ml brown bottle with a BB date stamp of july 2016. Enjoyed May 1st 2015 in Largoward, Fife, Scotland. 

6.7% ABV has limited impact on the aroma but does show clearly in the taste and feel. Nicely malty but with enough hops to keep an even sweet/bitter balance. Initially served too cold; improved dramatically with some warming.
UPDATED: MAY 1, 2015 Bottle from Co-operative. Pours dark ruby. Nose is lots of malts, bready malts, toffee, raisin, sweetish. Taste is quite sweet, malts, bitter toffee, caramel. Quite enjoyable.

Bottle from Aldi. Clear amber body with a thin off-white head. Steady carbonation. Light lacing. Aroma of brambles, plum, copper penny and caramelised sugar. Flavour of syrup, treacle and raisin. Medium body with an oily texture. Soft fizz. Id like to try this on cask - I cant believe the reviews are worse than for bottle.
Bottle at the 1780. Pours deep brown, nose is malty toffee, caramel, taste is similar similar, dry, sweet.
bottle pour at braukunst live 2015 in munich. medium brown with a reddish tinge, modest head; semi-sweet aroma of toffee and red berries; light bitterness, stonefruits; very drinkable

500ml bottle from Asda. Muddy dark amber. Slightly sickly sweet. Warming. Like an easier-drinking McEwans Champion, it's a not bad standby if you fancy something stronger.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark Bottle, best before May 2016. Smells slightly of bleach, but mostly sweet. Pours dark caramel, medium brown head, subsiding at an average rate. Taste is yeasty, malty, and delicious. Palette slightly rough, but very inviting. Great.

50 cl bottle. Deep red color, clear, creamy offwhite head. Aroma is caramel malt and cookies, plum, with fruity and woody notes and soft english hops. Licquory as it warms up. Taste is bent on the sweet side. Sticky sweet finish, earthy, quite warming.
Bottle from tesco. Big brown head. Dark red colour. Slightly nutty aroma and taste. Sufficient complexity with a good bitter bite.

Hazy amber color with a light off-white head, keeps a thin lace. Aroma is quite sweet with caramel notes. Flavor is also sweet but with some bitterness at end. Low carbonation and body with a smooth bitterness on the end.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone 4S

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2014 0.5l bottle poured in a chalice.
A: Beautiful dark amber color. Thin beige head with small retention.
S: Delicious perfume. Malt is quite strong. Honey and fruits. Yeasts in the end. Reminds a scotch whiskey in the nose.
T: Delicious taste. Bitter-sweet. Toasted malts, citric fruits (mainly grapes). Earthy yeasts and, if Im not wrong, also some oak can be felt. 
M: Medium body. Medium carbonation. bitter-sweet taste. Molasses sensation.
D: Good.
Terrific experience. Thats most probably a type of beer that could not be easily repeated outside of Scotland. I mean, it has a strong Scottish personality...
[ BA Review @ 2/21/2010 ]

Es una cerveza de color rojo oscuro.
Aroma a frutas oscuras, especias y lúpulos.
Sabor a frutas, malta tostada y caramelo. Final dulce y amargo picante y seco.
Esta cerveza es una excelente Ale Scotch, fantástico

Bottle, from Tesco, Kirkwall. Deep ruby brown, thin short lived white head, moderate condition. Gentle vinous fruity notes, some burnt toffee, sticky malt and a little yeastiness in the nose, quite bitter in the mouth with some plummy fruit notes and a little burnt caramel, slightly woody and with a touch of spirits alcohol, finish is figgy and yeast bitter
Bottle from Booths, Ripon. Pours mahogany with a cream head. Notes of coffee, toffee, raisin and a touch of sherry. Feels boozier than it should for the strength. A little harsh.
The higher ABV procentage gives this beer a sweet aftertaste, with a lot of herbal presence. The beer is not "hard to swollow" and is excellent with meat!
Pours a deep ruby red with a thin off white head. Aroma is all alcohol and fruit. Taste is sweet, fruity with very little aftertaste. Its ok. I was hoping for more.
Bue en bouteille. Bel équilibre darômes entre malts et houblons. On sent également la céréale grillée. Belle longueur en bouche.

500 ml bottle. Initial aroma is of roasted barley and notes of dark fruit possibly prunes or plums. Appearance is dark copper with a thin head - not too much lacing on the glass. The taste is excellent, sweet caramel and again dark fruits with enough of hops in there to balance it out with noticeable bitterness. The palate is quite thick and chewy and there is a hint of the alcohol in the after taste. Carbonation is limited in line with an old style ale. Overall this is a great beer with a lot of distinctive flavor.
UPDATED: MAY 18, 2014 Copper/dark amber. Good beige  head and lacing. Dark caramel aroma balanced with English hops. Similar taste. Well balanced. Not very carbonated. High drinkability.

"A classic Scottish strong ale, dark and strongly flavoured".
Dark ale, chocolate & caramel aroma, rich like a wine but not thick taste.

500ml bottle at home. Pours clear copper with a decent head and lacing. Big malt aromas, touch of alcohol, almonds, apple. Not as sweet on the taste as I thought it might be, good balance of bitterness. Some more toffee and chocolate coming through. Creamy texture, and finishes quite clean and crisp. Very enjoyable.
(Bottle). The scent is slightly sour with aromas of caramel malt. The taste is sweet and malty with notes of alcohol.

Bottle from Booths, Salford. Amber-red with a small bubbly head. Its strength is evident and feels much more than the 6.7% given its slightly spirit like aroma and taste, but like many old ales theres a clear sweetness about it too.
Brunröd öl med lättare smutsvitt skum. Doft av kola, mörkt bränt socker. Samma återkommer i smaken tillsammans med viss fruktighet med dragning åt plommon.

500 ml bottle, 1 year old. Pours light brown with short lived, small white head. Aroma is of sherry, caramel, chocolate and hint of hops. Body is medium and tangy. Caramel malt, herbal hops ripe cherries, pepper mint and wood fill the mouth. Finish is long, woody, peppery and dry. Very nice, complex brew.
Bottle. This is a big classic strong ale with all of the malt flavour and hopping to go along with it.

Ambrée limpide avec une très faible cargo. Petit col fuyant.
Aromes assez faibles mais agréables, fruits, caramel.
Corps moyen, légère amertume sur le final.

Bottle 500ml at Pub St-Alexandre.
Pours deep amber/mahogany with medium beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is of sugar, malt, peat. Taste is of malt, sugar, slight bitterness. Palate: Light-medium body. Overall: English. Not bad at all.
Golden-brown colour. Aroma is mostly caramelly, with a subtle fruitiness. Its a fairly basic beer. Not a lot of complexity.

Bottle (500 ml) @ Pub St-Alexandre (Québec). Best before March 2014. Clear mahogany with a medium off-white head and some lacing. Aroma is mild but interesting but toffee, earthy/mineral notes and light fruits. Taste is stronger than aroma, but far from overpowering. Toffee, earthy/mineral notes, light fruits and light floral presence. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Slightly sirupy body. Good English Strong(?) Ale. Not very complex, but enjoyable and well balanced. Interesting.

nett malzig-süßlich, schön rund, weich.
malzig mit leicht alkoholischer Note.
--> sehr lecker!
Bottle from Tesco. Amber color, white head. Bitter taste with caramel, alcohol, nuts, malts and toffee. Bittersweet finish with toffee and citrus. Good ale.

Thanks to BalkanMac for the bottle brought back from Scotland. A nice rich ale pour in to a tulip. Strong cherry and deep grape aromas, with some rich malts. The body is pleasantly rough before finishing with very fruity and nice notes. On bottle it makes a lot of sense and is tasty but I think Id have a different perspective on the beer if it were in the wild and in its own home bar. Tasty and rich, a fantastic ale, with fruit funky sour notes all around. Tasty.
Smak och doft av humle, malt, karamell. Fruktig och syrlig med en lätt beska.
Bottle at home sweet carmel treacle flavour roasted malt with warming alcohol light bitterness on the finish
A bottle of this frequently appears at Christmas.  I find it a bit too treacly.  It?s a very dark brown, strong tasting ale, with a bit of fizz.

Ruby pour, big frothy white head. Lovely sherry, sweet caramel, bready malty nose. Nice carbonation, solid mouthfeel. Semi bitter, dry finish. Subtle grassy hops, get lost in the really nice malts. A nice winter ale.
Come molte inglesi laspetto è ottimo con un bel colore ambrato e schiuma fine. Al naso malto in evidenza, come in bocca è ancora il malto protagonista.

Pours a hazy dark amber with a light head and spots of lace.  The taste begins with pure caramel malt joined through the palate with mild floral bittering and a lingering semi-sweet finish.  Not a big deal, but, quite enjoyable.  Recommended.
Bottle, pours a copper, aroma is quite earthy and flavour is too, the finish is a bitter, kind of stringent overall, it was drinkable

Rubin red light brown in colour. Pretty much no head, or fast fading. On the nose you have aromas of sweet, lightly roasted malts and chocolate traces. Full mouthed, full bodied beer with a rather oily slick light velvety texture. Nicely balanced. The finish is sweet and lightly dry.
Wasnt expecting th strong dark taste. roasty, resin, basement aromas, woody. Very woody actually.brown, cloudy, very bitter, full body, slick feel, fizzy, long finish. Not sure I would have another.

Sweety, raisins taste and nute of bitterness in palate. Somewhat roasted palate. You can feel the power of this beer whilst drink. White foam, stays for 30 seconds. Brown colour. The best Scotch beer so far.
Bottle. Murly brown with an off-white head. Sweet caramel and malt aroma. Caramal and biscuit flavour that is too sweet and ends with an ugly hop bitterness. Not very good.

Clear reddish brown, medium small but lingering light brown head.  Aroma caramel and brown sugar.  Medium body.  Overall mostly sweet caramel flavors, then a bit of bourbon-like quality and astringency.  Faint hops in the finish.  Not overly complex but well done.
Nice pint.  Sweetish.  Uncontroversial.  Fully rounded flavour although lacking some base notes. Light on hops, a bit more malt and a hint of caramel. Clean finish.

16.9 oz bottle pours amber with a off white head.  Aroma of caramel malt and  alcohol.  Taste is sweet and the alcohol.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Craig drunk at Naomis house. Very cloudy brown colour. Medium head. Fairly bitter.

500ml bottle in an English pint.  Pours deep amber with a lacy, off-white head.  Aroma of caramel and bread maltiness plus a little hops.  Flavor has the maltiness initially but then licorice and alcohol that is not pleasant.  Average texture.  A weird beer that might have potential.

Red-brown color. Aroma sweet, malt. Taste some sour, licorice, oil, CO2. Palate silken, sweet is changing into sour. Overall at a tasting

A nice amber brown body with a tan head that had some retention and decent lace.  Aroma had a nice fruity note up front, almost like apricots. Bottle. Medium body with some spicy aftertaste. Not the scotch ale I was expecting. Taste almost no scotch. Maybe I prefer wee heavy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rich fruit cake and crystal malt dominated old ale. Like the brutish older brother of Fullers 1845. Enjoyable, but a little heavy handed for me. Sweet, gooey caramel comes to the fore as it warms.

Mahogny color. Very malty nose of earth, cherries, wood, chocolate. Full rounded body with ton of earthiness. Superb. Full bodied, rich. Heavy for the alchol. A true winter warmer.  Full bodied, earthy, woody finish.
Nice.

A fine example of the style.  Drinking one out of the fridge right now, but I kept an open bottle @ room temp for a couple days and it stayed delicious on the shelf above my bed the whole time... Sign me up for a lifetime subscription!
500ml bottle from Tesco, Ayr - lovely strong fruity / barley malt aroma, clear dark brown ale with a foamy tan head, very sweet roasted malt barley flavour, fruity, smooth, excellent

500ml bottle. Dark amber with a good size fluffy head. Aroma is caramel malts, and predictably caramel also dominates the taste, along with hints of vanilla and fruit. An enjoyably sweet dessert beer, but difficult to sink a whole bottle.

From the 500 ml. bottle stamped BBE NOV 12 - L1132-14:09.  The pour is a handsome dark amber chestnut brown with a gracious amount of fluffy, light tan head. The aroma is subtle but pleasant with a welcoming dark malts, raisins, and sweetness.  The body is medium.  The taste  has an upfront sweetness with an above average bitterness at the end. Lovely.
an old bottle unfortunately, so take this with a grain of salt. water, thin kinda blah. one to try again someday.

I love this beer. Pours clear dark amber with a small head. The aroma is a ton of plums, prunes, grapes. The flavor is the same with just a touch of ho[s to keep some what of a balance. Excellent for the style.
It poured a dark amber color with a white head. The aroma was of roasted malts, cocoa and some dark fruit. The taste was very smooth with lots of roasted chocolate, malt and some dark fruit.
Bottle. Pours deep red brown with tan/beige head. Nice sweet, raisiny nose. Flavour of malt with caramel and a nod tward spice. Tangy aftertaste. A good strong ale.

Bottle (500ml from Tesco): 
Caramel, toffee and some solid earthy hops and malts make up the majority of this drinks aroma along with some background dark fruits and berries. It is very sweet and has a subtle burnt sugar note.

Mahogany brown colour with a finger sized, light tanned colour head that has a frothy, bubbly texture. Good head retention on this one, leaving a half centimetre thick foamy head throughout.

Sweet and malty in taste with brown sugar, toffee and caramel flavours all blending together well. There is some nice fruity notes at the tail end of the drink as well.

Medium to full bodied and mild carbonation with this beer. It has a quite creamy texture to it and a warm, bittersweet finish.

A rather nice, well balanced beer that goes down quite well that has a nice bittersweet finish to it. It is quite malty and as such probably not a beer that Ill have all that often but certainly one that I did enjoy.

1001 Beers Blog:

Bottle from Sainsburys, Nairn
Chestnut brown, slightly off white frothy head, minimal lacing.
Aroma of dark sweet malts, caramel malt, fruity - raisins, hint of spice, molasses, warming alcohol
Taste is quite complex.....rich complex malts -  dark sweet malts, caramel malts, hint of roast malt, bit of christmas pudding, raisins, alcohol infused fruits, bit of plum, alcohol well hidden
Finish of sweet fruity malt...smooth ..soft carb...medium oily slight sticky malt body...cleans well with a bit of warming alcohol
Ive ignored this at Tesco for a long time but this is a superb Scottish ale, very close to the Traquair ales. English Strong Ale ?????.......perhaps its the hops.....
Med en liten reservation för att denna inte var helt okej. Lågt skum, maltig syra, i princip bara maltsmaker någonstans mellan syrligt och sött. Lite platt dessutom.

Bottle from Tesco Danestone, Aberdeen. It pours clear reddish-brown, with a medium foamy beige head and moderate to high carbonation. The nose is chocolate, sweaty sock, dark fruit, raisin, currant and some bubblegum. The taste is raisin, currant, plum, chocolate, decent bitterness, tangy raspberry, strawberry, blackberry, wood, smoke, Christmas pudding and alcohol warmth, with a dry-tangy fruit finish. A very pleasant strong ale indeed.

Bottle from Sainsburys. A golden-amber ale with a thin white head. Aromas of raisons, dried fruit, caramel, some sweetness. Tastes quite fruity overall with some stewed fruits and well masked alcohol. Also flavours of toffee and Christmas cake. Nice chewy mouthfeel.

It pours a medium brown with a light white head, not much retention or lacing.

the aroma is light hops with a little what.

the taste is good and light but it has the aftertaste of a scotch ale ive yet to acquire. Its better than most scotch ales Ive had so were going in the right direction.
Mahogany with an off white head with lacing on the glass. Aroma of malt with a slight hint of vinegar. Nice malt taste with a hint of coffee. Smooth.

Bottle from Tesco. Aroma sweet malts with a bit of grass. Rich dark brown colour. Big strong flavour of malts with a hint of caramel. Slightly smooth and well balanced. I used to hate this one but my palate must have changed and I now find it OK.

Versa un colore rosso-ambrato, leggermente opaco. Schiuma molto cremosa e abbondante,di ottima aderenza e persistenza e con una buona effervescenza. Aroma decisamente alcoolico, poco pungente ma molto aromatico con note di legno e malto affumicato. Gusto mediamente pungente e corpo non eccessivamente acquoso. Piacevoli note speziate e cantina con finale amaro e alcoolico. Molto ben bilanciato anche se leggermente secco alla fine.
Deep ruby red colour with a white head and lace. Rich malt flavour. Quite fruity, whisky notes. Fruity rich ale. Full bodied, full of flavour. Slightly tinny with a metallic finish.
bottle, amber coloured beer medium white head. Shared on a bridge in bruges! Smell: roasted malts, hoppy. Taste: very nice hops, roasted malts, dry, oaky.

Bomber. poured a dark copper color with a big white head.  aroma of caramel and roasted malts with some spice.  taste is big roasted malts with a kick and the beer is nice and smooth as it rolls over your tounge.

Bottle, shared with friends. Amber coloured beer, medium beige head. Hoppy aroma, fruity and light sweet. Taste is malty, light sweet with a nice, hoppy, bitter aftertaste. Another nice one from Broughton.

Bottle. Pours with a finger of eggshell foam that dissipates down to about a centimeter but sticks around after that. Rich coppery brown color that is fairly opaque; has rising carbonation bubbles up the side of the glass. 

Ripe red grape aromas (nowhere near tart) and not all that sweet, which is interesting for the style. Some mineral and a bit of a hop kiss; very bready and hints of some sweeter maltiness. 

Very much into the red grapes and the fresh fruit tartness of that flavor sneaks in a bit; moves onto the maltiness associated with the style; bready and very nutty; almost a savory finish. Interesting departure from some of the sweetness associated with the more malt-centric takes on the style. Bit dry even though it has a fairly substantial body. 

Dont think that this is quite the quaffer as some others in the range, and it weighs in pretty well in the abv department. Nice, and a little dry helped things along. Not as warming as others, but still enjoyable.

From Peckhams, Glasgow. Copper with a slight, off-white head. Rich malty aroma with red fruits, caramel, nuttiness and a trace of marmite. The flavour was less complex: Sweet, bready malts, treacle, a slightly vinous edge and plenty of alcohol in the finish. Very enjoyable.
From a bottle poured a ruby color with a fair amount of head.  Strong sweet malty flavor with a quick finish.

Bottle from Scotland. Thanks Graeme! Pours deep copper with a big creamy beige head. Aroma of dark caramel and toffee. Taste is caramel malts,roast and some slightly smoked as well. Ends sweet peaty with a very moderate hops presence
Nice reddish brown pour. Very strong taste for the low abv. Lots of molasses and brown sugars. Rated 11/17/2000
Dark amber with a small head. Nice body. The flavor is a sticky-sweet caramel,  roasted Brazil nuts, vanilla, and a slight bit of fruits. Good beer.

500 ml bottle in Edinburgh. Medium amber-brown color with a tall, fine head. Rather sweet aroma, fruity, slightly roasted, with caramel and noticeable alcohol. Great malt flavor, with caramel and dark fruits. Sweet but very well balanced by roasted malts, hops, and a slightl sour-citrus aspect. Tangy, dry, sweet-and-sour finish. Fantastic.

03/03 0.5 l bottle courtesy of Doggythedog, thanks for sharing! It poured brown to reddish body with medium sized head that was going away pretty slowly. Weaker but fine malty caramel aroma spiced with some oak wood. Flavor was malty as well, mostly fruity and caramelly which was passing to licorice character. Wood is felt as well, alcohol is not. Pretty full bodied with very nice, long sweetish finish that was maybe more complex than the pretty simple flavor itself. Chocolate and some herbs showed up. Pretty simple, but really a pleasant ale.

Bottle 50 cl from La Maladière Centre in Neuchâtel (CH).
Copper colored brown in small off-gassing. Beautiful smooth and creamy beige foam. Tasty caramel malt round and sticky. Good beer, sweet and creamy, touches of butter and roasted. Final sweet, peaty, alcohol and hops. In short, an excellent "cru".

Bottle, Uddingston, 2001-04-12, Lovely scotsmen!
AP: brown/red body, rocky white head
AR: malt, caramel, toffee, cherries

Bottle from beershop.hr, shared with heavy Poured a red-amber body with a medium sized off white head that went away slowly. Woody malty light nose, sweetish. The taste is sweetish malty and woody, slightly yoghurty and soapy. No alcohol can be felt.  Ok, simple, drinkable.

Bottle from Malt & Vine. Dark, ruddy copper color with a multifinger foamy beige head. Aromas of floral hop over mild caramel. Medium minus body with near creamy carbonation. Flavor is floral, fruit and something cooked caramel with a touch of treacle, or may toffee.  Very UK, and definitely a good drink.
Dark brown with amber edges, foamy thin beige head. Arome of toffee, ripe fruit. Taste is a little dull with fruit and toffee. Thin tea-like body, low carbonation.

16.9 oz bottle. Pours a translucent caramel color, topped with a medium sized tan head. Sweet caramel aroma, with lots of peaty notes, and hints of fruit. Flavor is sweet, with caramel, peat, fruit, and a little oak. Medium bodied with light carbonation. Sweet malty finish. Decent, but not as complex as I remember it - but my last taste was 11 years ago.

londons big but BIGGAR,S BIGGAR Pours a clear, deep copper color with a big, lingering white head. The aroma is strongly malty with some smoke notes and a bit of alcohol present. This one has a medium body with medium carbonation and a very smooth and malty flavor. The finish is long and lingering with malty tones of smoke, caramel, and licorice. Smooth and delicious, this is a great Scottish Ale to drink and savour anytime of the year.

16oz bottle. Pours a crystal clear mahogany with a big  long lasting beige head. Thick and leaves ample lacing. Beautiful beer! Nose is equally impressive. Sweet caramel, an amazing banana bread aroma, hazelnut and raisin. Some molasses comes through as well.   Taste wise it doesnt quite live up to the amazing aroma and apperance but its still quite tasty. Carbonation is a little to prickly and the complexity isnt as refined as the Belhaven Wee Heavy. There is however a great lingering finish of toffee and caramel and a nice heavy mouthfeel. Some raisins come to play at the beginning but its fleeting. The middle part of the palate is dominated by sweet bready malt and yeast and a slight hop tick at the end. Probably one of the better traditional wee heavys out there. This is slightly smokey as well but that doesnt really come in to play until the beer warms to near room temperature. Still a welcome addition to the flavor profile. This is one everyone should try because its so undeniably Scottish and also so beautifully crafted. Very very nice.

Old Jock. I think this is why I didnt used to like most ales. I used to buy this fairly regularly and it was wonderful, I loved the hell out of it; and then I would drink another ale and it would pale in comparison. It was pathetic really, the other red ales; especially a few days or weeks after Id had an Old Jock. It was such a great ale.

Then I stopped buying it for almost a year. I bought one the other day becase I figured I should rate it now that Im rating things on here, and wondered how it would compare now that I have started to enjoy more and more ales.

I poured it about two minutes ago, a dark amber color. The head was thin but present; clinging to the glass. 

The bottles sweet too, makes me think about being a kick ass guy with a big beard and shit. Hes got a nice thick mustache, the kind I keep trying to grow... I mean I have a sweet civil war mustache and all, its really pretty badass; but this guys stache/beard combination blows mine away. Just like it continues to blow away all the other ales.

I remember now why I bought this regularly.

The smell is hard to pick out, barely present hints of caramels and malts.

The taste is a beautiful cacaphony of caramels and malts and flavor. It stikes me as what an ale should taste like. The best ale Ive ever had.

Thick and heavy in the mouth, a little creamy from all the caramels. There is a presant but not overwhelming level of carbonation.

I should buy it more, in fact I will buy it more. I wish I had bought more as Id like to crack another one open.

A nice aged sweetness to it but there is something in the finish which lets it down a little. Overall a pleasant surprise. Liquorice and raisins in the flavour too. Actually its more maple syrup than toffee.

Bottle. Pours bronze with a decent size large beige head. Aroma of fruit, slight roast, and caramel. The flavor is smooth, fruit, roast, with a slight alcohol kick in the finish. Good body, good brew.

deep reddish copper with a large light tan head.  not much aroma except some cherry and malt.  awesome cookie flavored malts on first sip.  also some fruit in the middle.  pretty nice beer.  i really love the bready malt character.  im really grossed out by the name though.

Expected a lot more from this as its one of those ales Ive been keen to taste for years now. Given the chance, Id rather have kept it at fantasy rather than memory. Bright copper body with a good firm beige head that retained for the length drabbing froth down the glass as it went. Big salted, roasted peanut and pretzel nose with fresh-baked Anzac cookies thrown in. Very similar in the mouth flavour-wise. Good solid base of bready malts layered in toffee, salt, pale nuts and smothered with marmalade. Alcohol is present in the back, slightly warming, slightly chemical. Sweetish, doughy finish with a gentle tang of oranges and some very filling malts. Too heavy without the backing of well-defined or characterful flavours. Pretty bland overall. It may well have been a plate of pretzels and peanuts with a shot of vodka to follow. Average. (50cL, BBE 05/07, some pub on the Scottish borders, Scotland)
Served at room temperature out of the bottle.  Beautiful brown/ruby color with big thick head.  Sweet, caramel nutty aroma.  Perfectly carbonated beer with a slightly sweet, malty flavor.
Chestnut colour with a creamy off white head. Malty, vague roasted aroma with a dark fruit sweetness. Light roasted malty flavor with anotes of raisin and prune.

(Bottle BBE 05/07) Caramel, slightly roasted malty and slightly fruity aroma. Red brown colour, very slightly sparkling and white, average, almost fully diminishing head with some lacing. Sweet, caramel and slightly bitter flavour. Medium to full-bodied and very softly carbonated palate. A good ale! 12/06/06

Bottle. Poured a brown color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted and had fair lacing. Moderate caramel dark fruit aroma. Medium body with a creamy texture. Medium sweet flavor with a sweet small alcohol finish of moderate duration. Good brew with a good cigar.

Bottle. Great red-brown or mahogany colour with white head. Aromas of berries and flowers and a weak tone of caramel. The body is a bit thin for such a strong beer, but it has a great nutty taste with some burnt tones. Not vinious at all. Some raspberries appear in the aftertaste.

Poured a orange to brown color with a very pillowy slightly tan head that lasted for quite a while and laced very well. The aroma was somewhat smoked and of dry fruits (an interesting combination). The flavor was of peat smoke (like a scottish ale), some fruit flavors, some butter, and with some roasted coffee malt type flavors in there. Finished somewhat dry relative to a scottish ale, and had the mouthfeel (lightly acidic) of other old ales Ive had. The alcohol doesnt really hide in this one, but it is enjoyable.

Bottle.
Clear orange coloured with an off white head.
Aroma of malts, caramel and fruits.
Flavour of malts, caramel, fruits and hops.

A sweet malty nose. A nice head with a lasting lace. This beer has a sweet fruity flavor with good maltiness. A decent palate not over carbonated and smooth in the mouth.  I drank one glass straight out of the refrig and let the bottle sit while I sipped it. Do yourself a favor and dont drink a drop of it below 50*.
Pours a nice deep dark reddish brown color.  Big sweet malt aromas with  hints of dark fruit.  Flavor is a dark fruity kinda tart with the slightest tingle of metallic at the finish.

Bottle pours a deep copper with a decent sized off-white head. Aroma of fruit, citrus, and sweet malts. Flavor is sweet, alcohol is present, caramel, fruit and a metallic finish (might have killed this brew for me). good body, ok brew.

Dark copper color with good head. Sweet caramel aroma with strong fruity and alcohol esters, suggesting orange and mango. Full bodied sweet and malty flavor. Some tart metallic and alcoholic notes. Caramel- toffee finish. Too caramelly and unbalanced for me.
Caramelly nose, dark amber color, low fluffy head. Sweet malt, raisin tastes, figs too. Brown sugar as it warms. Light wood end. Medium body. OK, but not that great.
Thanks Juha!! Red colored with a small head on top. Fizzy carbonation. Raspberry taste - also some spiceness- nice. Medium sweet caramel with yeast nose.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2007 Bottled 0,50L. Much creamy and bulky foam, optimal adhesion and persistence. Burnt red color, lightly hazy and with good fizz. Alcoholic and decided scent, little pungent but a lot aromatic. Winy with notes of braced malt and smoked wood. Medium pungent taste with a round but not excessive body. Pleasant notes of cellar and spices with bitter and alcoholic end. A lot balanced even if lightly dry on the end.

Bottle 13/08/2002
Mid brown with some alcohol present. Very fruity flavours and a slightly dry malt finish.
This brewery is not bad. 3rd try from them.  Chestnut body with foamy tan head. Malty nose, with some fruit and spice.  Lots more in the taste. Quite nice .

Bottle. Pours bold mahogany with rocky beige head. The aroma is rich caramel and prune, with a bit of banana and yeast. The mouthfeel is a little thinner than I had expected, but the flavor is still quite robust. Lots and lots of burnt sugar, some subtle hops, banana, plum, and a fairly clean yeasty finish. Not something I would drink on a regular basis, but a refreshing brew to revisit once in a while.
Poured brownish red with good frothy head and excellent lacing.  Aroma was yeasty.  Taste was a bit acidic with a sour finish.
Brown Coloring with Sandy Head.  Tart and Lightly Fruity Aroma and Taste.  Light Hops in the Background and Finish.  Nice Simple Ale.
Dark amber color. Well malty Ale, some sweetness, a lot of caramel, some malty fruitness. Solid brew, satisfactory.

16.9-oz bottle.  Pours clear and clean maple mahagony brown with a small frothy head that becomes a bubbly, rocky film floating atop the brew, with some fair spotty lined lacing.  Medium roasted sweet caramel malt (cookie) aroma with a fruity hop nose and some port, vinous characteristics as it warms.  Roasted caramel malt flavor, medium bitterness and acidity follow, with fruit hops and a port, wine-like finish.  Medium bodied and fizzy, lively carbonation, refreshing palate.
SDmells good - full caramel. This beer is pretty grainy but nice. Also, the hops are slightly noticeable but far from prevalent. A rare good Scottish.
Dark amber, thick white head. Fruity, citric nose. Malty, slight bitter flavour with a little acidity. Not overwhelming, but still drinkable.

Big, thick, chewy, caramel malt aroma with strong vinous, fruity notes.  Clear copper-brown body is topped by a generous, fine bubbled, off white head that recedes slowly to a lasting cover with some lacing.  Sweet, malty caramel flavour up front is joined by a pleasant dark fruitiness with some hints of roastiness and fair bitterness in the finish.  Some sherry like notes.  Dry medium body with very soft, texture offset nicely by lively carbonation that engages the tongue.  Pint glass.  Cellar temperature.  Bottle (BB Jan-06, State Line Liquors, MD, Oct-05).

Bottled. 
Brown colour. Malty backbone, notes of almond, fruits and licorice. Good body. Slightly sourish. Would never guess its 6,7 %.
This is a pretty good beer, its got about the right amount of body for an ale of this type, with good balance between malt and hops.

Dark amber color, little vanishing beige head. Chocolate, mild licorice, some sweetness and cherries in aroma. Medium bodied. Chocolate, mild licorice, sweet flavor with mild alcohol in the end. Aftertaste lasts with sweetness. Medium carbonation.

500 ml bottle from Bello Vino in Ann Arbor, MI, best before Dec 04.  Hmm, and oldish bottle, that might be a good thing in this case...pours a dusty dark brown with a thick near-white head and lots of fine lacing....gently oxidized and vinous chocolaty-caramel nose, touch of cherry and hickory nuts...rather delicate on the palate, subtly malty with dried fruits, sherry and some dry woodiness...just a touch too sour towards the finish (perhaps it IS too old after all) but a nice sipping experience overall.
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2006 What this beer contains?, It has an apple sweet aroma with alcohol smells, and really sweet in the flavor, but really strong too, I liked it, but almost got drunk.

Bottled. Dark copperish brown colour with mediumsized foamy beige head. Aroma is plum, alcohol, hops, raisins and caramel. Flavour is sweetish bitter, plum meets hops and some weak hints of alcohol. Also some roast in aftertaste.

This pours a dark caramel brown with a fluffy tan head that reduces to a bubbly haloed film.  The aroma is a musty toffee with a touch of smoke and earthy nuts.  The flavor is a hardy, heavy sweet malt, nutty with ripe apples, licorice, and a bit of alcohol.  The finish is dry and lightly bitter... slivatingly so.  I will be having more of these in days to come.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2005 500ml bottle (pasteurised), from Beers of Europe, two months past its best before. Bronze/red colour. No head. Slight carbonation. Aroma has bags of toffeeish malt and is very vinous, going on malt vinegar.  But theres some wet paper and a hint of vomit in there too. The flavour is better than the aroma. Sweet sherry, fruit cake and licorice. It is rather sweet, but theres  a lot of acidity to offset that. I ended up rather enjoying this beer.

Bottled (BB 02/2007)
Beautiful clear dark amber color with big CO2 bubbles and good foamy tanned head. Oaky, nutty, quite typical ESB&Old Ale nose. Medium-bodied. A bit roasted and nutty with, hints of licorice. A bit caramelly, also slightly metallic mouthfeel. Some hops in the finish. Somehow this reminds me about Fullers ESB. Not in its class however.

(Bottled) Clear, dark amber color with a very small head. Slightly roasty, sweetish-caramely aroma with nutty toffee hints. At room temp, its a bit smoky and alcoholic. Caramely, sweetish, roasted-malty flavor with mild licorice hints. Roasty, nutty and bitter in room temp. Medium-bodied, smooth palate with quite low carbonation. More ashy and foamy in room temp. Not very complex, but a reasonably full and pleasant ale.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2005 I totally dug this beer. Scottish Ales are usually not on my list due to their ash-tray flavor qualities. However, this jocky was pretty tasty. Poured a nice reddish-amber. Smelt slightly smoked and had great robust flavor. This beer should be served room -temp. Changed my perspective totally. After a bottle of this Scottish brew i found myself in a Hagas eating contest with a forehead full of blood from too many Glaskow kisses!! OYYYA!

appearance is nice darker than expected with large head, nice. Aroma is malty, slightly bready, stable maybe. Taste is not as complex as expected for a beer of this strength, alcohol well hidden. Would like to try it again.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2007 I was not sure what to expect from this one but found myself to be quite pleased.  Sampled from a 16.9 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark chestnut color with a medium sized creamy tan head.  The aroma is sweet, tangy and has a strong note of molasses. The flavor is strong molasses with tangy ripe fruits underneath. There is a deep malty molasses finish. I will be coming back to this beer again.
Bottle from Tesco, Fort William. Pasteurised. Dark brown/red. Aroma of malt, toffee, fruit. Full bodied and malty, sweetish. Not unpleasant - Id like to try on cask.
Big head upon pouring which reduced quickly.There was a slight vinegar aroma when first poured which didnt impress me.Brownish appearance and a reasonable body but all round not that impressive/

Freed from its glass enclousure, Old Jock pours a clear caramel-y brown color, with lush, creamy head. Nice enough lookin...
Aroma, nuts, dark fruits, creamy malt, but all lightly played, nothing too stand-out. 
Crisp, clean taste, malt dominant, same dark flavors from the nose, return on the tongue...plus a hint of maple and molasses, a trickle of treacly caramel and toffee, berries and grapes. An easy drinker, too, quite smooth, passes past the lips with remarkable fastidiousness.
Medium bodied, faint, fruity finish.
A good bottle of brew, but nothing to knock your Granny over to get.
Amber colour with a off-white head. Malty raisin aroma and taste. Medium body and a light spicy finish.

dark copper pour nice mushroom tan head. nose of dark fruit and sweet malt.  full bodied palate with sweet malty flavors, tobacco, oak, figs and rock candy sweetness.  a little more robust then i expected. good.
Brown color with a thin head.  Slightly smoky and almost bacon-esque aroma.  Malty body with a pinch of fruit and a sour finish.  Nice!

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2005 (Bottle 50 cl) Dark, reddish ale with a fine, light brown head. Very full and sweetish with a lightly smoked touch and some bitterness in the palate. Fully balanced. A lovely wee one... 010404

A long standing favourite. This is a big full flavoured beer, fairly dark in colour with a good firm head. The nose is malty and fruity,there is a complex palate dominated by sweetish malty notes, but with well balanced fruity hop flavours as well, has a long finish...all in all a VERY satisfying brew. All Broughton beers are excellent, well balanced and of a superb quality...if you havent tried them..go on treat yourself...NO! I dont work for them, I just enjoy their beers.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2006 [Cask from Tennents Bar] malty nose with dark fruits and bread. full bodied , slightly smokey with a very sweet, heavy palate and a dry finish with a kick of alcohol. too sweet, difficult to finish a pint.

Pours ruby-brown with a thick tan head that fades quickly.  Malty aroma, with ever so slight amounts of wood and/or peat smoke.  Flavor is fairly malty up front but drier on the finish.  More hop bitterness than other Scottish beers, but appropriate for the style.  Well carbonated.  Pretty smooth and enjoyable brew.
Bottle. Dark amber-red with small head. Sweet, raisins, toffee, slightly woody and lactic flavor. Medium body, initially quite fizzy.
Nice looking dark amber colour with slim off-white head. Sweetish, smokey malt and caramel aroma. Malt, dark fruits, caramel and some late hops in the taste. Very smooth, full bodied, very nice.

Ill happily dance to this pipers tune. This is a blockbuster old ale that would conceivably complement red meat and some cheeses. Its a dark tan colour and poured with a modest head. Fantastic nose: treacle and spice notes. Its full-bodied and complex. Treacle and toffee notes on the tongue, with some spice in a lingering finish. Plenty of malt. Has a port-like character that would make it a decent complement for food. A personal favourite. (Bottle)
Bottle 500ml.Light brown in colour,small head,the taste of dead wine and eat me dates,very fruity and makes your ears go red.

Bottle. Tastes quite scottish, sweet toffee and peaty malt flavours. Nutty, with a touch of berry fruit, a little sweet and slightly sticky, with a warming finish. Not many hops to note, its quite malty.

This was really tasty and pleasant. The taste seems to consist mainly of (different kinds of?) malt and some yeast I should think...there was a taste I was unable to pinpoint but it tasted familiar, like a certain nut or fruit that eluded me... Overall, a very good beer, although probably not one Id want all the time.

Best before DEC 04 drank in OCT 04:  Clear ruby orange with a thin off-white head.  Doughy nutty malts in the aroma with a touch of brown sugar.  Lively yet smooth mouthfeel, starts and ends lightly sweet with a long pleasant aftertaste.

Dark brown beer with a thin white head.  Caramel and butterscotch aroma, a bit of cherry fruit.  A bit highly carbonated, but shows nice complexity, caramel malts, cherry and berry fruit, slight hint of molasses sweetmenss.  Brown demerara sugar as well.  Finish is long and sweet, mostly caramel with a bit of spicy hops.

Dark reddish brown pour with thin off-white head.  Left good lacing though for the extended amount of time it took me to drink this bottle.  Fruity, malty sweet nose wth alcohol and a little cherries.  Sweet and fruity, cherries, a little port and peaty, earthiness.  A little thin and watery though.  Palate is OK.  Flavors blend well but all in all a little thin all the way around.  Definitely drinkable but not one of the best.

(on bottle)Being fan of this particulat beerstyle, I´m surprised. My impression of old ales are that they have alot of layers and depth to them. This brew smells like fresh cut apples and, though it has a small roundness, the overall impression is sour. Very irritatating to the palate-sour. I once commented the hops on the bottle(Golden border) and again; way to much hopping for my palate. And where is the fine ageing of an old ale in this; it´s very youngish and perky.

Thanks to CAPTRON for sharing. Pours a reddish brown. Medium tan head. Aroma is toffee with fruit and some mild earthy notes. Taste is watery toffee with more fruit and a mild hint of wood and some earthy/peaty notes. Mouthfeel is moderate with a decent carbonation bite to it. Finish seems like mild cocoa or caramel mixed with slight fruit and malts.
Bottle. Reddish brown in color with a tan head. Fruity aroma. Fruity sour flavor. Very fruity beer. Malty. Ok beer.
Pours a reddish orange, with a tannish head. Rather fruity aroma. Very fruity sourish flavor, with a big malt backbone. Fruity finish.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Old good Jock. Beautiful chestnut/copper colour with an OK head. Aroma of grapes, cherries and dark malts. Rich winey and fruity flavours. Very respectable Scottish ale.
Pours nicely from the bottle.  Tastes like a tea sweetened with Sweet-N-Low.  Not bad, but not as good as other Scottish offerings.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottled; Clear dark amber coloured. Huge off white lasting head. Sweet and malty aroma with a light cocoa note. Flaovur is light spicy, malty, sweet and has some vague hops notes. Is rather full in the mouthfeel. Is dry and light sweet in the end. Has a vague bitterness.
Dark copper in color, a little bit on the heavy side. Malty fruity nose. We can finally get it in Georgia no more late night runs to the Tennessee border
Reddish brown coloured. Some vinegar notes in the aroma. Slightly sourish flavour. Smooth mouthfeel.
Chestnut color with a white head. The taste is sweet rather plain and smooth. Light fruity notes.

Wow.  Thanks to the manager of The Old Toad for this one.  I guess they found this one somewhere and called it "cellared" for 5 years.  Im not complaining.  Aroma: amazing, very complex, with notes of apricots, wine, sour grapes, cherry.  Flavor: Lots of flavors here, speaks to being aged for 5 years, very complex, sweet malt, sugary fruit, smokey scotish ale.  I was damn impressed.

Large frothy head, rapidly diminishing to a nice sheet of lace. Clear reddish amber in colour. Nose is lightly malted with a bit of fruityness (cherries?). Flavour is malty, slightly acidic with dried fruits and some subtile anise really comming through in the aftertaste. Alcohol is nearly absent except in the finish. I would have expected more malt from the Scottish, regardless, quite a good drinking ale especially with this abv.
UPDATED: MAY 7, 2007 Dark red and quietly active with a giant head.  The aroma is malty and cherry-toned.  Likewise, the flavor is sweet and fruity, accompanied by a nice smooth body.  Nice.

Dark red mahogany color with a light cap of head and a little lace. The aroma is full of nuts and fig with some roast & calamata olives and some malty cherry notes. The flavor is well balanced with some semisweet charactaristics, nicely caramelized. The finish is well rounded and balanced as well. This is a pretty good beer, some balanced complexities but nothing too outragous. Semi-session you could say.
Bottled. Amber with a fine white head. Bitter hops sharpen a malt base. The palate and flavour created from the hops is more astringent then bitter.
Ruby color and tan head.  Aroma reminds of whiskey and some fruit and woody tones.  Flavor was good.  Full and satisfying.

500 ml. bottle.  Pours a deep copper brown color with a medium sized light tan head which quickly dissipated.  The nose was of malt and caramel and a slight whiskey aroma.  The flavor was primarily rich and malty with malts lingering in the finish.  This is a good Scottish Ale.
An excellent Scottish ale, Old Jock displays a complexity of maltiness in both aroma and flavor. So many different malt aspects make this a pleasure to drink.
bright ruby-brown colour, few foam, cherry and malty nose, full-bodied, slightly oily with an acidic touch, nice late bitterness in a long fruity and malty finish - fresh, robust and balanced

Aroma is quite strong and very pleasant. Brownish appearance with a moderate head. Flavor has a little alcohol showing through with nuts and grapes being the primary flavors. Very nice beer and I really didn't enjoy Scottish Ales at first but they are starting to grow on me.
UPDATED: JAN 13, 2004 Sweet and fruity (plums, grapes, or something like that...heck, I don't know!) aroma and taste with bitter finish.

I think I like the Black Douglas better as it is a bit darker and richer.  This was more of a lighter amber ale take on the style.  A little bit lighter and softer, with some different flavors coming through, lighter fruits and more hops but still very tasty.
A red beer with a fine head. Both the nose and the flavor is sweet and malty - a very nice beer.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2003 This is a superb old Scottish ale. The complexity of the flavor is the highlight of the drink. Tangy and berryish, but not sweet. Kind of like berries that aren't yet ripe. Smells like iron, and nuts. Awesome.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2003 Poured almost opaque amber hue with reddish tint when held to light. Thick, quickly disapating head. Nice lacing. Aroma of smoky malt. Nice warmth and smoothness on the palate with a lingering mild sweetness. Smooth finish. Great brew. Very impressed.

Reddish copper hue with a big frothy off-white head that produced outstanding lace. Aroma hinted of grapes, berries, chocolate malts, light pine, and floral garden flowers. Taste and mouthfeel was intitially sweet and smooth then developed a acidic twang and minor smokyness. Lingering fruitiness on the palate. The unique flavors can throw some for a loop, but I found the combination excellent and not boring. I recommend to anyone who likes Belgian Lambics or fruit beers.

Clear ruby orange hue.  Roasty smokey nose.  Chocolate and fruit.  Small light beige head.  Pleasantly light-footed on the palate.  Caramel, biscuit, leather, light to medium bodied, cherry, faint smoke, stone, and wood;  folding into a crispy, lightly herbal hopped finish.  Very drinkable, and better with warmth.
fruity/malty aroma, pours with a dark ruby hue and a white head, cherries/strawberries with malt undertones, very thick palate with a lingering sweet finish.

very hazy with an odd color..looks kind of like french fry grease that has been used about ten times too many. not much of a head though. aroma is pure butter and caramel in the malts with hints of wood and earth. flavor does have a little hint of sourness with a sweet finish. it looks heavy in the glass and as if it might coat your tongue, but it is quite drinkable. this one surprised me as i've never even heard of it, not to mention finding it in arkansas..cool find.

Clear red colour with a large tan head, malty nose, with just a slight hop accent. Tasted a little dull, mainly malty, flat, nice bitterness but it lacked any real strength of character to make it stand out.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is dark amber. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel), lightly hoppy (flowers), hint of whiskey. Flavor is moderately sweet, heavily acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, heavily acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. A 3.7 average for this?! It's on the top ten Scottish ale list? Suuuuuurrrre...if you like the aroma boring and the flavor very sour. Yet again, well before the best before date so no reason for me to think this is ruined.  Infected at the brewery maybe, but I think this is just the Broughton way...Black Doug and Merlin's were both sour as well despite being "fresh". Drain pour.
Copper color with a large rocky off white head.  Sweet caramel malt aroma.  I found this way too sweet, the palate clinging, and the aftertaste, well like an old jock smells.

Just a few months past the "best before date", this reddish-brown brew offered a very light aroma of dirty, earthy malts and a slight oaky or woodiness.  Although caramel was the dominant malt flavor, it was not as sweet and enjoyable as I like.  Sort of jumbled at the end with strange smokiness and a bit harsh, maybe from the strange and high amount of carbonation. I left 1/3 of the glass.

Pours a clear, deep copper color with a big, lingering white head. The aroma is strongly malty with some smoke notes and a bit of alcohol present. This one has a medium body with medium carbonation and a very smooth and malty flavor. The finish is long and lingering with malty tones of smoke, caramel, and licorice. Smooth and delicious, this is a great Scottish Ale to drink and savour anytime of the year.

Pale red color, with a medium-sized thin white head, slightly cloudy. Aroma has caramel, malt, oak notes, burnt oranges, and a bit of creaminess. The aroma seems a bit confused to me, not bad, but not great. Flavor is malty, with caramel and orange and a bit of sweetness. Very carbonated. Overall not a bad ale, but I've had better scottish ales.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 The aroma of the ale reminded me of fruit. It is definitely not a typical aroma for me to sense. The head was very carbonated with very fine bubbles that lingered a long time. The taste was different for me and I am having trouble describing it. Many fine bubbles continued to rise from the bottom of my glass well after I poured it. The color of this ale is a pleasant medium amber. Overall, I liked it, but I much prefer the Bocks and the porters.
dark full bodied scotch ale. very malty stuff here with only a trace of hops. taste is rich and has butterscotch, peat and whisky.
Yes, I see that this beer is well liked.  I personally did not like this bready malt that was used, very average ale.  Sharp in front but boring at the end, soft light bitterness. Thanks Doug!

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2003 Clear dark amber colour with a respectible beige head. Caramel malt and wood smoke in the aroma. A little light on the tongue, but the flavour is nice and smooth, with the caramel and smoky malt suggested by the aroma, and some licorice & vanilla hovering around the edges. Could do with a bit more assertiveness in the finish, but otherwise, it's a solid brew.

This beer mega-kung fu rocks the house!
Crystal clear, lovely deep amber hue. Small, creamy, khaki head. Slowly, but mostly diminishing with poor lacing.
The aroma is vineous and tart. Tawny port and red wine vinegar come to mind. Notes of purple grapes, American White Oak, butter and grapefruit. Caramel notes surface as the ale nears room temperature.
The flavor has vineous (tawny port) blasts with lightly sweet bursts of dark fruit and lightly pungent hints of buttermilk up front.
Well-balanced with a nice hop addition and tart on the tongue on the backside of the flavor. A whisper of warm alcohol creeps its way down into the abdomen.
Medium-bodied with a very creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Long, fizzy, dry finish.
This beer is a great example of why Scottish Ales are my favorites.

If not a poor man's Fuller's Vintage, then at least a petit bourgeois's Fuller's Vintage.  This has wonderful lacing and a big frothy head.  THe nose is caramel, fruit, spice and wood, perfectly setting up the balanced flavor that mirrors it.  So smooth, so noble.  Top notch.  My sample expired January 2002.  Held up beautifully.
Malty and sweet aromas and flavor. Reminded me of Traquair Ale a bit (nowhere nearly as good though). Very smooth and drinkable Scottish Ale.
Nice caramel sweetness on the beginning, with slight fruitiness spiciness in the middle. Good caramel nose. Very little head over a deep copper body. Very pleasant finish. Good beer for cold weather.

Dark amber colour.  Aroma is malty, caramel, some chocolate.  The flavour is the first Broughton beer that I have had that is not watery.  This one was slightly sweet, soft chocolate and caramel.  Finishes with a nice caramel maltness.
Description is right-on, slightly sweet with a hint of licorice.  I cant say this tops their Merlin Ale but this is good in its own sense.

Pours to a slighty frothy head which quickly dissipates.  Great dark amber/orange color and clarity.  Hint of plum? in the aroma.  Definate taste of licorice in the mouth along with some sweetness of caramel.  Little weak on flavor though.  Light end, medium bodied ale which goes down smooth with a slight warm of alcohol.  A decent beer in a great bottle.

Peachy and appricot aroma with a light touch of alcohol.  Copper color with a head that get thin very fast.  Nice fruity taste that does not seem to go in any one direction other than light friut.  Finish is on the sharp side.  Good but not great, It could use to be a litlle more flavorful.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2003 delicious sweet-malt-hop flavor (that is to say, well balanced - there are many flavors mingling here) beautiful color! It's a pitty that I was only given 2 bottles of this. must try some more.
Nice scottish ale aroma, a bit like Gruyere cheese.  Coppery-amber color, little or no apparent head.  Nice bittersweet flavor.  I still prefer Orkney Skullsplitter, but this is still quite good.
pours clear brown, off white head doesnt last.  roasty, slightly buttery aroma.  malty, with faint chocolate and alcohol.  not bad.
Sweet/sour aroma, with oxidized hops.  Stale flat cardboard flavor.  I hope this was an old bottle.

Cloudy brown color, Dissipating head with lots of lace. Aroma reminds me more of a Belgian dubbel than a Scottish. Flavour is along the same lines, fruity/malty, but not as sweet as most Belgians, and therefore more to my liking.

Deep red almost black color. No head to speak of. Smells like mollasses and fruit. Starts sweet with an a mild anise flavor. Finish figs/dates that lasts. Bought this a the grocery in Creif. I didnt wait for it to chill. Poured and drank in the car on the way home.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2004 Started in 1979 by David Younger of McEwan and Younger, Broughton changed hands in 1995 and has managed (somehow) to gain a reputation for decent beers. This Scottish Ale has more in common with an English Old Ale: a good strength used to add depth, and lots of complex chopped fruit embedded in a malt jelly base. Initially pleasing it soon becomes apparant that this is a beer flexing its over-inflated muscles into a parody of a sugar coated muscle builder. The result is an Arnold Schwarzenegger fruit cake dipped in rum and Fairy Liquid. Unbalanced and crude - there are better Old Ales (or English Strong Ales) around. Try Theakston Old Peculier for example, or - if you can find it - Stonehenge's Old Smokey. [2.8]   And again...  White Cliffs Winter Ales Fest. Gravity.  Sweet. Acidic. Not brilliant. [2.8]
